headline.main: ENIGMATIC F.A.A. CHIEF: J LYNN HELMS

results.snippet: Soon after he took over as the new head of the Federal Aviation Administration, J. Lynn Helms asserted that the agency ''will, at my direction, stay out of the press as much as possible.''   But if freedom to practice his quiet brand of...

byline.original: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Soon after he took over as the new head of the Federal Aviation Administration, J. Lynn Helms asserted that the agency ''will, at my direction, stay out of the press as much as possible.'' But if freedom to practice his quiet brand of behind-the-scenes management was a major goal, then the slim, 56-year-old former Marine Corps test pilot chose the wrong government job. Avowedly ''nonpolitical'' and publicity-shy, he finds himself at center stage in the air traffic controller's strike, which has developed into a major test for the new Administration. To this task, associates said, he brings a decisive style - cool, analytical, heavily dependent on facts and detailed knowledge - that helped him gain a reputation as an executive who could help save ailing companies. He came to his job as head of the aviation agency after six years as head of the Piper Aircraft Company, which he brought out of a financial tailspin.

results.snippet: Nineteen Americans and two Europeans became the newest astronauts, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced here today. Eight are to become pilots and 13 are to be mission specialists operating equipment and scientific...
results.lead_paragraph: Nineteen Americans and two Europeans became the newest astronauts, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced here today. Eight are to become pilots and 13 are to be mission specialists operating equipment and scientific experiments during flights of the space shuttle.

headline.main: Shuttle Said to Perform Well In Mock Blastoff and Landing

results.snippet: The space shuttle Columbia performed ''like a champ'' today in a mock blastoff and emergency landing before its second flight, scheduled next month.   ''I've gone through a lot of spacecraft tests, but never through one that went as smoothly as...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Columbia performed ''like a champ'' today in a mock blastoff and emergency landing before its second flight, scheduled next month. ''I've gone through a lot of spacecraft tests, but never through one that went as smoothly as this one,'' said Thomas Mattingly, one of the backup pilots, who along with Henry Hartsfield, an astronaut, was at the controls of the shuttle for the tests.
